snippet.textDisplay:
I uninstalled my Blizzard launcher and haven't played or even considered playing a Blizzard game since the FreeHK fiasco. I'm disappointed that so many of my contacts have gone on as if nothing has happened, but a few others dropped Blizzard and haven't picked them back up too.

I also haven't gone around telling everyone I've done it because...well, I don't think anyone cares. I wouldn't care if someone told me. Maybe the people who say they will boycott and the people who do boycott are just different people.

Also, possibly gamers as a group aren't very resilient and give up when game producers don't immediately fold in the face of the threat of action. If you're going to take action, you have to accept that the action is going to hurt you too. You're engaging in a contest of will with any kind of consumer action; it's not for wimps.

tl;dr If I don't like a product, I just don't buy it. RIP to your controversy but I'm different.

snippet.textDisplay:
When was the last time any boycott worked?
I'm pretty sure that was before I was born, if at all.
Vote with your wallet!
Just a pointless way of saying to boycott them.
It still doesn't work.
Internet petitions have some value, but not much.
If you want to influence a company, and you don't have billions to spend on it, send them actual physical put it in the post type letters. Lots of them.
Companies that don't even notice a boycott, that ignore internet petitions with tens of thousands of names, sometimes respond to a measly 100 actual letters.
Yes, I mean the type you actually write on paper. If you go email, that's like the internet petition, ignored. If it doesn't have a stamp, it's not going to work.
Yes, that does mean you'll have to get out of your chair to mail it.
If you can get hundreds of people to send actual letters, you might get a response.
Thousands of people will get a reaction, even if they don't make it public.
Tens of Thousands of people mailing letters will get almost any company to do something. Even if only because they can't just press a button and pretend they didn't exist.
They also know how lazy everyone is, and anybody that will go to the lengths necessary to send a real letter is worth more than thousands of internet mouse clickers.

Of course nothing will get corporations to act like caring sane humans, but they can be persuaded to pretend for a while.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think you are underestimating a current trend (at least in PC gaming) where people do not have the time or money to invest in more than one game a month. Hell one article said in 2019 spending on PC gaming was down to like 200 dollars a year.

Now the boycotts might not seem to work but they are, slowly. It takes a lot for people to abandon a company now a days, but they do and it does hurt the company. How? Well since all the companies want all the money, shipping less means less money, which leads to closures and failures as they can only continue to milk those they have till there is nothing left.

The game industry wont fail like some say but the big companies will fail. They will merge, hostile take over and liquidate eventually because they can not meet the insane expectation to make infinite profit off of a finite consumer base. They will fail and then some of your beloved companies now like CDPR will start the cycle anew.

snippet.textDisplay:
Oh my God ! FINALLY someone is calling people on their bullshit...

That's what I've been saying for YEARS now... every time I hear about a so called "boycott" for a game or a studio I can't help but roll my eyes because I know FOR A FACT that this is very often all barks and no bites... How about some of these "GaMeRz" grow a pair and actually DO SOMETHING instead of just angrily typing on their keyboards about how "AnGeRy" they are ? how about they actually don't use the service or simply don't buy the damn game they are seemingly "boycotting" ?

I for one boycott AAA games that are not good or are mediocre at best, and even tho sometimes in the past I really wanted to play them, I was simply cracking the damn thing because I didn't want to give them a single cents... is it morally questionable ? Yes, is it undeserved ? No, at least I don't think so, because if your game is mediocre then you should expect people to crack it because they don't want to support YOU for the piss poor game you made or for your anti-consumer practices

Overall, these boycotts made by so called "GaMeRz" are often times, nothing but dogs angrily barking at the other guy on the other side of the fence... it feels all powerful and mighty but when the guy gets over the fence now it just shut up and lays down for a pet

snippet.textDisplay: Can we really say that the SnS boycott "didn't work" following Game Freak's back peddling of cut Pokemon and deciding to include them via DLC? As a disclaimer, I'm not a Pokemon fan and I've got zero dog in this fight. But just saying, from my outsider perspective, the huge shitstorm of "controversy" may or may not have affected Game Freak's bottom line, but the outcry definitely got their attention. A lot of media attention is given to the exact sales figures following a boycott, but the greater purpose of a boycott is to incite change in the game or developer. It's not merely to spite them (well, I'm sure for most gamers, it is, but that's not historically what it is or what it should be).

snippet.textDisplay:
Boycotts aren't things to be forced, they naturally happen but noone of recent years has remotely enough charisma to force one to happen. People who truly agree will naturally boycott, if enough agree it will be successful, if it doesn't oh well at least I saved money and voiced displeasure. However I don't really like when a boycott fails then those boycotting start berating people who bought into it.

Just because you point something out isn't going to change someone else's mind who made it up. Boycott is a self-choice and should be about laying information out on the table for who want it rather than forcing it. Some who do boycott act similar to game journalist where they try to berate anyone who thinks different.


That being said, I never agree with boycotts don't work. For example pokemon, that game has stopped being a "franchise" a while ago and shifted to be a "cultural" thing, all someone will ever see is what was purchased and not how much would've been bought. However I do believe that if the game released fully cooked and transparent about dlc instead of 3rd game and premium bs was attached to the online service to beef it up it could've even touched lifetime sales of prior recent pokemon with how much people love it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I personally boycotted Blizzard from the time they took down Nostalrius until they released WoW Classic. It was admittedly pretty easy, though, with them making Starcraft II expansions free and otherwise just not releasing anything I was tempted to buy in the meantime. Then I got tired of WoW Classic and quit it XD I guess I'm back to boycotting them again, mostly because they're still not selling anything I want today, with the possible exception of Warcraft III Reforged. But since they fucked that up pretty badly, that's $30 or whatever they won't be getting from me, of course.


In the end, that is all a bunch of selfish gamers can accomplish - personally choosing what to spend their money on, and what not to. Same as every other class of consumer. The failure of "boycotts" isn't limited to games, by the way. Just look at people going out of their way to buy products made in the USA, for instance. Their personal choices aren't putting cheap imports out of business. They probably aren't even enough to make US-made products more viable than they otherwise would be. Principled, self-controlled consumers definitely are a small minority whose purchase dollars are a virtual drop in the ocean.

End of the day majority of gamers like you tubers are kids, most of which have no clue about "the discourse" as most of them talk to each other on their headsets rather than on reddit, and tiktok and insta are not really places for articles. YouTube channels which are most likely now pushing to show they are for adults to keep their adverts are likely the closest kids get to seeing the point.

So unless one is boycotting over something they wouldn't be embarrassed to get out and tell parents not to buy it for their kids over, which let's face it most these boycotts are not things people would talk about to non gamey people because they know it sounds silly, there isn't much point.

If there is a proper ethical reason that could be done but most of that spans more than one game or company. I'd imagine some right wing protestors could get some parents on their side, but once it's split on politics it's going to be far from the majority who boycott.

If people joined to protest and boycott with parents over all games with microtransactions that'd be something but then there is the task of getting 13-15 year olds who online game on board when this is the main form of socialisation for a lot of young boys these days so...

snippet.textDisplay:
I like Pokemon Sword and Shield and never agreed to boycott anything. The community was more split about it than they think. Black & White had a lot of hate and they "fixed it" with Black and white 2. earning even more cash. So why would they not fix it later? As they probably will and kinda have with the dlc.
The reason I like sword and shield however might have to do with my hatred for how boring it was to play Sun and moon. I think as a casual player of Pokemon that restarts the game several times and then play it with a new team every time. I did not hate the new game instead it was more fun.

However boycotts does only work if it's only gamers that buy games... we are not.. I have co-workers who are parents and they buy EA games over and over for their children. They did not even know what EA is doing in the games. So when I told them they where shocked.
Gamer boycotts only work if everyone agrees to it... even non-gamers. So I agree to the video, complain so that more people know instead of going "we should boycott" to a community of thousands /millions when there are billions of people in the world.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am accounted for in sales numbers. I am a target for the game industry because I spend money in it about once every 4-9 months (lately exclusively in the indie market). I am marked for not being interested in several games because I care enough to look at the quality of a game before making a purchase.
Me not buying a game due to quality issues does no damage to the numbers projected.
Choosing to only buy games because of your reasoning is a good thing, but don't misunderstand the game industry. Its a high volume market that even having 50% of the customers boycott the game it will be able still be a massive success. This isn't even touching on the idea of people who say they join a movement and don't fallow though.
If you going to not buy a game just say that, don't use the word boycott. It makes your word mean something when your only place to hide is by your actions.

snippet.textDisplay: The thing is, especially with a big, long existing franchise like Pokemon, a lot of the fans aren't part of the 'gaming community' by which I mean the people that are really on the internet pushing conversations in the culture, for good or bad. Most of them are adults that get an ad for pokemon somewhere every couple years and that are like 'let's give this a spin for nostalgia' but aren't really in the loop. Or it's simply children, who don't care like that. If their favorite isn't in the game, they'll find a new one in 25 minutes. The 'gaming community' is very vocal, but it's also tiny compared to the fact that 50% of all people play some kind of video game regularly.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm against the notion that "gamers are bad at boycotts", because it's really nothing that is limited to gamers alone. There have been these incidents where certain brands like Nike and Gillette who don't really care about women (Gillette is even famous for their pink tax) purposefully targeted right by their actual target audience and advertised to women and diverse people to trigger a reaction and boycotts from their core fans. This caused boycotts to happen because some right-wing people on the internet burned their Nike shoes and razors. The boycott caused the media in response to write articles about that which in turn created a lot of positive attention for those brands as well as support against the boycott by everyone else who didn't like nazis. And it isn't even coincidence. It might have been a coincidence the first time, but now it's a calculated strategy to cause those boycotts, because they do exactly what good advertisement should do, but cost way less.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think you are missing one major point: A lot of the games being boycotted are major, even downright mainstream games (FIFA, CoD, Pokemon). The fans, the gamers(TM), the people who are informed about gaming know what's up and why a videogame should be boycotted are the ones calling for a boycott. But with mainstream games like that, they are a small, yet vocal minority.
While of course there are people shouting "boycott" and then buying the game, a way bigger issue are the millions of people whose sole contact point with gaming is "going to the store, 'Wow, they actually released another FIFA/CoD this year!', going home, buying the lootbox-starter-pack, playing the game". These 80% or more of people who play videogames make even the most through boycott by gamers(TM) almost entirely void.

And people, especially media-outlets, think that the boycott encompasses literally everyone who plays videogames, when it's really only the 5-20% who "know their gaming". And of course, those are going to say something about a boycott, while the other 80%-95% aren't going to conclusively write "we aren't boycotting", so it looks like the boycott fails because the non-boycotting-side wasn't properly noticed.
Nevermind that even among the informed gamers(TM) there are people who might not mind some new changes, while others do.

snippet.textDisplay:
Meanwhile I'm approaching roughly a decade of not having purchased any Ubisoft game after they fucked up my precious Splinter Cell franchise with that goddamn corridor shooter they had the gall to call Splinter Cell Conviction. I mean, they made it easy with just generally releasing basically the same game with different skins ever since though it took me a little bit of mental fortitude not to grab The Settlers III and IV History Edition when they were like 2.50€ each because I loved the shit out of those games back when ... but no fucking deal with mandatory Uplay.


Likewise didn't buy a single EA game since Battlefield 1 (so a bit more than 3 years to date), though I'm not going to lie: if the Command and Conquer remaster/remake reportedly in the works shapes up like promised (not that I have a lot of hopes for EA to stick to their grand promises, but I'm always happy to be pleasently surprised against all odds) I'm going to be hardpressed not getting that one (still salty AF over EA axing the CnC franchise out of the blue in the middle of the promising Generals successor alpha).


I'm under no illusion that me not buying games somehow is going to effect any change and I know lots of people are two hump chumps when it comes to sticking to their precious boycotts because at the end of the day most people have a fuze instead of an attention span and forgot all about the problems as soon as the next hypetrain comes rolling in ... but I for one do feel a bit of satisfaction everytime the big publishers pull another stunt and I can legitimately say that I'm not one of the sheep bleating "boycott" only to buy the next game in whatever franchise they were complaining about next.


If ye can't be riding the cheques to the bank, ye can at least ride the high horse, yeehaw!!!






Same reason I'm more than happy to wait out "The Outer Worlds" 1 year exclusitivity deal until it lands on Steam. Not that Steam is particularily better (though on the technical scale it no doubt is ... does the EGS got a store cart yet?), but I really don't have any interest in having half a dozen proprietary game libraries/launchers installed and in addition to that, by the time TOW lands on Steam I wouldn't be surprised if I could buy myself some form of GOTY edition with DLC/blahblah included for the same price (or perhaps even cheaper) than what the basegame cost at launch on the Epic store.

snippet.textDisplay: Even if I'm just one dude, I refuse to pay for the garbage being shoveled out by these companies. It's like the fallacy of "my vote doesn't matter" here in America. Although that's correct, in the grand scheme of it all, if everyone approached voting with that mindset then things would kind of fall apart. Leading by example and speaking with you action is important, even on an individual level. I don't buy games from EA, Ubi, Blizzard, or Activision and I've been doing so long before people truly started hating these companies. I won't be buying a Pokemon game again, I won't be playing a single second of Warframe until the day I die, nor will I be paying for a Nintendo console anytime soon. It's very unfortunate people simply don't care that they get walked all over by greedy, corrupt companies, but I can be proud of myself for living by what I preach. I think it's important to, truly, vote with your wallet. There are far too many fantastic games to play in one lifetime, why play one that's made without morals when you can find something just as good, made by people who really care about what they're doing?

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like there's multiple facets to why gamer boycotts fail in the modern age. While yes, cases like the MW2 example in this video do happen, there's also the possibility that the rally for boycotts can divide a fan base, consequentially making two groups: one group where people who were going to buy decided not to due to changes or malpractice, and the other group where people who may have had decided either way, but are emboldened to buy the game to push back against naysayers. Obviously both of these groups are over represented on social media platforms, but it seems to me that it's possible that this division of a fan base significantly impacts sales of a game that's seen as controversial, which is what I think happened with Pokemon Sw/Sh.



With a fan base as diverse as Pokemon, people come to the games for different purposes, whether it be competing, collecting, or just to enjoy a new story. Sw/Sh before release was going to fail the needs of collectors and it makes sense for those people to boycott the game, however their reasoning fell upon deaf ears of the competitors and explorers that come to play Pokemon, so there wasn't any unanimous agreement on whether this was going to negatively impact Sw/Sh as a whole, which said agreement is crucial to any effective political or social movement. That's not to say that collectors shouldn't have voiced their opinions on the game, quite the opposite actually, but I think the notion of a boycott sparked counter protest in the form of the large sales numbers we see today.



So while yes it is important for those rallying for a boycott to keep their word, in some cases a fan base might be too large for a boycott to even matter. I think the best ways for people to not monetarily support games on social media nowadays is to not give them free press/attention, avoiding showing anger in opt for disappointment, and to offer attractive alternatives to the games we love instead.



So tl;dr, Play Temtem.

snippet.textDisplay:
People keep assigning the failure of "Gamer Boycotts" to people complaining and then buying the game anyway; I don't think that's what it is.


I think the outrage is real and that the people who are outraged (I mean beyond expressing their outrage by a single click, like joining a steam group) often don't buy the game, but there's three major problems with turning the boycott into success:


1) Advertising the boycott advertises the product, as a quote in the video mentioned, increasing brand/product awareness and catching new potential customers.
2) Even the expressions of anger with the most agreement (like the Battlefront 2 reddit post, most downvoted in history) are too small to make a difference. Even if every one of those people didn't buy the game, it would be ~600k sales lost on a game that sold what, 12 million?
3) Boycotts around microtransactions are especially difficult, because they're not nearly as reliant on initial sales, and the people least likely to buy microtransactions are the most likely to boycott and the people who buy the most microtransactions are unlikely to boycott it merely over the presence of microtransactions. One big spender can off-set hundreds of boycotters, by themselves.


I think that point 1 and 2 apply to boycotts in many other arenas; Nike was recently boycotted and their sales went up (see point 1) and boycotts of Starbucks are completely invisible in sales figures (see point 2). I think, in reality, it's not just "Gamer Boycotts" are destined to fail... it's all boycotts of businesses above a certain size (i.e. international or similar).

snippet.textDisplay:
Blizzard was a company I loved for around 2 decades. I bought every release on the day they were out, then when preorders became a huge thing, I preordered everything. Now, I refuse to buy anything with the names Blizzard or Activision attached to them. What they did in in cow towing to an evil regime, they pretty much stole from fans via prize pool money, and now WC3:R, has made me extremely certain of one thing: Blizzard as we knew it exists in name only. Activision has beaten it's internal rival at the expense of the fans and that for me is unforgivable. My $$$ won't make a difference to their bottom line, but my conscience is clear in not helping out an enemy of the playerbase.


I played WoW since beta, so the amount of money I gave to them over the years is a decent amount. The Diablo franchise was my favourite though, hands down. Even though I watched the videos for Diablo 4 and thought it looked amazing, it broke my heart because I know I'll never play it. That might sound dramatic, but this was a company that was at the top of my favorite devs for near 20 years, so to see them fall so far, so fast, it's disgusting it can happen. I don't care what anyone else does, but it does tarnish my views on them as people when they knowingly fund people being openly subservient to tyrants who commit mass crimes against humanity.

snippet.textDisplay:
Err, I still think the cel-shaded Zeldas look like shit.
I didn't need a boycott or anyone to tell me that. I noped out and stayed out. I absolutely despise that art style. It's in a sort of uncanny valley for me where the "cute" has just dipped horribly into "sickening." I would have told them to burn it all and go back to pixels. I would have told them to go back to the freakin' N64 Ocarina engine rather then let that pass quality control. I'd almost rather look at something by Andy Warhol.

But then, perhaps it's just me.

snippet.textDisplay:
People not sticking to boycotts are definitely a big problem with gamer boycotts, but I think especially with the games talked about, they fail moreso because they have a large audience of people who don't give a shit.

Call of Duty is/was (I dunno where it stands these days) "one of those" games that are popular among people who aren't typically gamers, that can be the only game a person ever plays maybe alongside Fifa or Assassins Creed. Most customers probably don't know there's a """boycott""", let alone know what it's about...Alongside the minority of boycotters who can't even stick to their own boycott of course.

Pokemon, again, huge franchise, hell of a lot of customers that haven't heard of and don't care about a boycott. You've got people who don't actually play games buying it as gifts for younger people, hardcore fans who are going to buy both versions on release regardless of quality...Then this minority of loud people trying to boycott it, even though most won't.

But that's only two franchises and one other example of why they fail. Gamers being useless is still a large reason why.

Its really easy to NOT do something, NOT buy something. Everyone needs to heed what the immortal words of Totalbiscuit were, which was to not buy things instantly and NEVER pre-order.
Every gamer needs more conviction and self restraint, or just a shred of patience.
This kind of shit is why EA made a nigh billion dollars on microtrasations the past couple months.

snippet.textDisplay:
Well, why do boycotts, especially of high profile games not work?

Simple observation, firstly, a lot of people will already have preordered... meaning, the money is spent, they get the game to their house, and they are by definition core gamers, because else they wouldnt know of the game coming out or wouldnt care. A lot of these just dont bother to try and refund it, as its usually barely possible to do so.
Preorders do not follow the same laws, as normally buying the game. Even in the EU you dont have your two weeks of refunds.

In addition, often the game, while not officially released is already playable for people who preordered, before the shitstorm actually comes, as was the case with wc3R
Even if there are any consumer protection laws, they technically had the product for a long time and thus cant give it back.

Which then brings us to the second group of "Boycotteers" people, who say the game and the company has to be boycotted, but are also too curious to not spend the 20-60 bucks on a game, they know isnt gonna be very good. Especially today with half of the gamer population being hobby streamers, people feel the need to get in on the action, if just to be able to have an opinion on the game.
And this is also something that I found funny with Sterlings video about negative reviews, there was one person who says they didnt play the game, and ofc it makes sense to say "Well then I wont take you srsly" but on the other hand, by that merit, we require everyone to buy it, just to have an opinion about the game, which makes boycotts even harder.

Then the main group of boycotteers. They are strong willed to not buy the game. So they dont. Then there is a lot of press coverage, a lot of people saying how they hate the game and sooner or later they realize "Hey, I didnt buy the game, but seemingly everyone else did" and over short or long, they will either have moved on and actually skipped the game or they will still buy it.

And then there is the last group, casual gamers, who just do not care for the boycotts and the forums and all the junk around the games, they just want to play a game, and to stay with wc3R they may go "Hey, wc3 that was something I played 15 years ago, super cool, a new HD version" and they then buy the game play it, and get exactly what they wanted, just an HD version of the game they played 15 years ago.

So to make it short, only very few people are actually ever gonna be able to boycott games, especially when people actually want to play them and only the circumstances are bad, like in the case of wc3R

snippet.textDisplay:
Speaking for myself, I stick by when I say I'm not going to get something. Lots of better games out there to play instead.
In the case of Shield/Sword, I didn't get them because they clearly didn't put their all in them and explained why. Then kept at it when people would ask me questions and/or when new news came up on it. Not to follow a boycott.

I wasn't expecting there to be any meaningful hit towards the game sales due to me or others not getting them, especially since I know even bad publicity is still publicity and thus attention. Though it is pretty sad when people cave and get the games they boycott anyway because of what I said and should be known: There are better games out there. It's like... you know it's going to be bad then buy it anyway? Way to waste your money, lol!

snippet.textDisplay: Boycotts go this way because they only gather momentum in the tiny echo chambers that these “hardcore elements” reside in. It’s easy for a boycott to look huge when you have a few hundred passionate people talking in the same space, but that rarely resonates with the wider general public.
